Module.name: S0 - Auto-formation orthographe et grammaire
Module.description:
Pour aider les étudiants qui recherchent des pistes d’amélioration de la qualité de leurs écrits, le LabTxT d’EPITECH met à disposition des étudiants des ressources d’auto-formation sur l’E-learning. 

Il existe deux types de ressources d’auto-formation : 
-	des fiches au format .pdf,
-	des mini-sites au format .html (une archive .rar qui contient un fichier index.html et tous ses fichiers annexes).

Les ressources d'auto-formation ne sont pas des cours complets, elles ont pour but d’aider les étudiants à résoudre des difficultés ponctuelles (accord des participes passés, ne pas confondre à, a et as, etc.) en leur proposant quelques éléments d'information, des pistes de réflexion, des exercices pour s’entraîner. 

Contrairement aux fiches en format .pdf, les mini-sites d’auto-formation (en .html) sont interactifs : il est possible de réaliser les exercices et de visualiser immédiatement les résultats.

Module.name: S0 - Coding Club
Module.description:
Le Coding Club est un atelier récurrent qui permet aux lycéens de s’initier à la programmation et au développement. Il est disponible dans toutes les écoles Epitech de France ! Les ateliers d'apprentissage (stages durant les vacances, sessions le mercredi ou le samedi) sont animés par des étudiants d'Epitech : les CoBras

Ces étudiants passionnés se réunissent régulièrement au sein du Hub pour bidouiller, apprendre et faire découvrir des technologies variées (web, mobile, game, arduino…).

Ce module ne donnera pas lieu à l'attribution de crédits

Module.name: S0 - Ecriture de Fiction
Module.description:
Module optionnel d'écrits de fiction ouvert à tous les étudiants (Tech1 à Tech5).

Ce module propose un projet par an, disponible lors de deux sessions (Session1 / Session 2), il n'est bien sûr possible que d'être noté une seule fois sur ce module.

Vos fictions doivent être de qualité publiable.

Ce projet vous donne l'occasion de laisser libre cours à votre imagination pour rédiger un texts selon un parcours ludique et créatif.

Vous réaliserez ce projet à partir d'une amorce de récit ou d'autres éléments (sons, images) procurés par le LabTxT dans les consignes.

Pour le rédiger, vous pouvez décider de vous associer quelle que soit votre promotion et la région EPITECH où vous suivez actuellement votre cursus d'études.

La taille du groupe d'étudiants est définie dans les consignes de chaque sujet. 

/!\ Attention : ce module ne peut se poursuivre au delà de la fin de votre semestre de fin d'année d'études. Il sera clos pour votre conseil de classe.

Vous ne pouvez vous inscrire qu'à UNE SEULE SESSION  parmi les 2 proposées et pourrez obtenir ainsi au plus 1 crédit.

Module.name: S0 - KYT/CAT - Cyber Security
Module.description:
This unit is a roadblock in tek1 and in tek2 : you are expected to validate 1 cycle in Tek1, and 1 cycle in Tek2.

The purpose of this unit is to introduce you to some parts of computer culture and to instill and generate an interest in these various subjects. 

The key word of this unit is "serendipity" meaning : ‘the fact of finding interesting or valuable things by chance’. By using recommended sources, the idea is to expand your research according to the topics you wish to address. 

This unit is divided into several parts and it is essential that you understand how it works: 

Each cycle of KYTCAT (Know Your Tech/Crack A Trivia) includes 4 major areas of work and lasts 6 weeks. 
- The project registration gives you access to the resources that are the basis of the unit. 
There will be some resources available to prepare your MCQ. Take the time to read, watch, and listen to these resources, they will be used as a base for the MCQ. 

- The MCQ’s on Moodle each include 20 different questions, concerning the contents of the resources. 
This MCQ is the gateway to present your pitch. If your QCM score is not high enough, you can not go to the next step. 

- The pitch will be an opportunity for you to present a specific aspect of YOUR research, linked, of course, with the theme of the cycle. 
You are to avoid factual presentations and instead seek analysis, synthesis and criticism. (duration: 10 min, Q/A included)

- The written version will resume the main arguments of your pitch and will be in the form of an infographic, taking again the sources which you will have consulted to prepare your presentation. The purpose of this exercise is to provide a common basis to make available to students. 

All these elements together will allow you to validate your unit. If you reach the minimum expected score from the first MCQ, you will be able to gain a +1 grade in the unit.

Module.name: S0 - KYT/CAT - Network & Communication
Module.description:
Ce module est barrage en Tek1 et en Tek2: il vous faut réussir un cycle au cours de chacune de ces 2 années.

Ce module a pour objectif de vous présenter quelques pans de culture informatique et de vous inculquer le réflexe de vous intéresser à des sujets variés.

Le maître mot de ce module est "sérendipité", laissez-vous porter par les sources conseillées, puis étendez vos recherches en fonction des sujets que vous souhaitez aborder.

Ce module est divisé en plusieurs parties et il est indispensable que vous en compreniez le fonctionnement:

Chaque cycle de KYTCAT (Know Your Tech/Crack A Trivia) comprend 4 grands axes et dure 6 semaines.

- L'inscription au projet vous donne accès aux ressources qui sont à la base du module. Il y aura là de la matière pour préparer votre QCM. Prenez le temps de lire, regarder, écouter ces sources, elles serviront de base au QCM.

- Les QCM, sur Moodle, comprennent chacun 20 questions différentes, portant sur les contenus des ressources. Ce QCM est la porte d'entrée pour pouvoir présenter votre pitch. Si votre score à ce QCM n'est pas suffisant, vous ne pourrez pas accéder à l'étape suivante.

- Le pitch sera pour vous l'occasion de présenter un aspect spécifique de VOS recherches, en lien, bien sûr, avec le thème du cycle. Vous éviterez les présentations platement factuelles, pour chercher l'analyse, la synthèse, la critique (durée 10 min, dont Q/R).

- Le rendu écrit reprendra les principaux arguments de votre pitch et se présentera sous forme d'une infographie, en reprenant les sources que vous aurez consultées pour préparer votre présentation. L'objectif de ce rendu est de constituer une base commune à mettre à disposition des étudiants.

Tous ces éléments réunis vous permettront de valider votre module.
Si vous atteignez le score minimum attendu dès le premier QCM, vous pourrez gagner +1 grade au module.

Module.name: B4 - Functional programming
Module.description:
Functional programming is a paradigm of programming that focuses on algorithms. In other words, it focuses on the evaluation of functions and the limits of the technical effects. We define a technical effect as something which modifies a function's execution environment. For example, a global affectation or writing on the standard output. In this way, in functional programming, we let the compiler handle the memory, the allocations and the code optimizations, which allows us to focus on the algorithms. 

Functional programming and imperative programming are complementary. This is why properly mastering both paradigms will make you a better developer, one who is able to adapt to virtually any programming language. Furthermore, functional programming is a fundamental component of numerous other paradigms, like reactive programming.

This way of programming, often unfamiliar and unfairly considered to be "too complicated" or "too detached from the reality of programming", is, in fact, a boon for a programmer's knowledge. 

There are numerous functional languages, which encourage this way of programming, like Haskell, OCaml, Scala, Erlang ou F#... it's a long list.  A number of imperative languages, like C++, Swift and JavaScript, now incorporate functional parts.

You will use Haskell, which has the huge quality of being a genuinely functional language, and offers a very comprehensive standard library and numerous external libraries. 

You will find a lot of information about Haskell at the following address: http://haskell.org

Warning: there's no such section as "Functional programming" in your E-learning. The exploitable learning resources will be indicated in the bootstrap documents.

Module.name: B4 - Mathematics
Module.description:
Probablilty and Statistics Unit.

This unit is the continuation of the units from B1 and B2. The skills required to validate the first two units need to have been acquired. You must be able to create algorithms by using mathematical methods, and be at ease with graphic tools (plotting different kinds of curves).    

SUBJECTS COVERED:
The unit consists of two sections: 5 probability classes and 5 statistics classes. 
1° Probability: random experience, events, probabilité, random variables and a few famous discrete or continuous variable laws. 
2° Statistics: descriptive statistics, statistic adjustments, correlation, survey sampling.

SKILLS TO BE ACQUIRED in order to validate the unit: 
There are two types of skills required to validate the B4 unit:

1° mastery of more complex scientific computing algorithms (formula decoding, combinatorial computing analysis, without intermediate storage in memory...)
2° ability to manage complicated numerical calculations, which requires a good, preexisting comprehension and intelligent implementation (descriptive statistics parameters, correlation parameters, expected value and variance with numerical integration...). 

You must be familiar with the fundamentals of probability and master several classic statistics methods. 
You will be evaluated through the completion of 10 mini-projects.

Module.name: B0 - English - TEPitech
Module.description:
What is TEPitech? 

TEPitech stands for Test of English Proficiency at Epitech. It is a language exam you are supposed to take regularly throughout the year, until you pass it. It is an on-site automated exam, for which you need your computer, internet connection and headphones. Please note that the self-assessment exams are unsupervised sessions, whose sole purpose is to allow you to assess your progress. They won't count towards validating the unit.

What is it for ?

This test is used to assess your English comprehension level, from year to year, in preparation for the 4th year abroad. Our partner universities expect you to have a minimum English level at the end of the 3rd year – at least 750/1000, but some of them would like higher scores.

Therefore, the target scores are divided into 600 (tech1), 700 (tech2) and 750 (tech 3). The score has to be validated every year, even if you score 750 in tech1, you will still have to take the test in tech2 and tech 3.

What does it look like?

The test is divided into two main parts (oral comprehension and written comprehension), which, in turn, are divided into several sections.

You’ll be tested on your comprehension, as well as on your grammar and vocabulary, in both business and academic domains.

The browsers that work best are Chrome/Chromium and Firefox.  Plug-ins and extensions are prohibited and students are requested to use full screen mode so that we can verify that no extensions or plug-ins are running. 
 
Students who do not use Windows/Firefox etc. do so at their own risk.

Validation specifications

Terms and conditions

Tech1

In tech1, you need to score at least 600/1000 on the test before the end of the current academic year.

* Credits

The TEPitech doesn’t give you any ECTS credits. The credits are counted toward the English unit.

* Roadblock

In tech1, if you don’t score 600 on the TEPitech, you must validate enough language skills (see English unit) to prove that you’ve been working hard on your English. During tech1 you need to obtain at least 25 skills over the course of the academic year.

Let’s recap:

* 600 on TEPitech: no roadblock for tech2.

* Less than 600 at the TEPitech, 25 skills validated, no roadblock for tech2, See below.

* Less than 600 at the TEPitech, less than 25 skills validated, roadblock for tech2.

Language training abroad

If, despite the workshops and the use of e-learning, you experience difficulties in improving your English level to meet the required standards, your local educational team may advise you to consider leaving for language training abroad. This doesn’t necessarily mean that you’ll have to attend English classes abroad. You are advised to look for a summer job in an English speaking country. When you come back, you’ll be asked to take a TEPitech in order to qualify for tech2.

Tech2

In tech2, you need to score at least 700/1000 on the test before the end of the current academic year.

* Credits

The TEPitech doesn’t give you any ECTS credits. The credits are counted toward the English unit.

* Roadblock

In tech2, if you don’t score 700 at the TEPitech, the unit becomes a roadblock: you cannot enter year 3. Remember- on top of that, you must validate enough language skills (see English unit) to prove that you’ve been working hard on your English. During tech2, you need to obtain at least 20 skills over the course of the academic year to gain your ECTS credits.

Let’s recap:

* 700 at TEPitech: no roadblock for tech3.

* Less than 700 at the TEPitech: roadblock for tech3, See Sabbatical year.

Sabbatical year : Language training abroad

If, despite the workshops and the use of e-learning, you experience difficulties in improving your English level to meet the required standards, your local educational team may advise you to consider leaving for language training abroad during a sabbatical year. This doesn’t necessarily mean that you’ll have to attend English classes abroad. You are advised to look for a job in an English speaking country. When you come back, you’ll be asked to take a TEPitech in order to qualify for tech3.

Tech 3

In tech3, you need to score at least 750/1000 on the test before the end of the current academic year. Nevertheless, your application for Tech 4 is to be submitted at the end of January, so we advise you to score as high as possible by then.

* Credits

The TEPitech doesn’t give you any ECTS credits. The credits are counted toward the English unit.

* Roadblock

In tech3, if you don’t score 750 at the TEPitech, you cannot access Tech 4 and, subsequently, our partner universities. You must also validate enough language skills (see English unit) to prove that you’ve been working hard on your English. During tech3, you need to obtain at least 15 skills over the academic year.

Let’s recap:

* 750 at TEPitech: no roadblock for tech4.

* Less than 750 at the TEPitech: roadblock for tech4, See below for sabbatical year.

Sabbatical year : Language training abroad

If, despite the workshops and the use of e-learning, you experience difficulties in improving your English level to meet the required standards, your local educational team may advise you to consider leaving for language training abroad during a sabbatical year. This doesn’t necessarily mean that you’ll have to attend English classes abroad. You are advised to look for a job in an English speaking country. When you come back, you’ll be asked to take a TEPitech in order to qualify for tech4.

Module.name: B0 - Hub
Module.description:
There are 4 levels of investment in Hub activities:

  - acculturation
  - sharing
  - experimentation
  - fruition

  There are several types of activities in the Hub, that you can witness, organize or even fully manage:

  - HubTalk
  Conference of a pro or student / former alumni on a tech subject generally held in the HUB (activities are planned on the HubTalk module - B-INN-001)
  PARTICIPATION is about acculturation (1)
  DOING IT is about sharing (1)

  - Workshop
  A few hours of experimentation to discover a tech project / concept
  PARTICIPATION is about experimentation (1)
  ORGANIZATION is about sharing (1)

  - FocusGroup
  A group of students focused on a technical project and offering demonstrations (including possible Workshops)
  PARTICIPATION is about experimentation (2)
  ORGANIZATION is about sharing (2)

  - Hackaton / Jam
 Short-term (usually 1 weekend) challenges in or out of school
  PARTICIPATION is about experimentation (2)

  - Maker Projects
  From the simple project of discovering something technical to an ambitious and published project, everything that takes the form of a concrete realization, alone or in a group
  REALISATION is about fruition (1 to 2 depending on the size of the project)

Depending on your academic year, total investment in these activities provides a number of credits:

1 credit:  at least 4 acculturations and 3 experimentations
3 credits: at least 4 acculturations, 3 experimentations and 1 fruition
5 credits: at least 4 acculturations, 3 experimentations, 1 fruition and 1 sharing
8 credits: at least 4 acculturations, 3 experimentations, 2 fruitions and 2 sharings

The Tech1 can validate 1, 3 or 5 credits (the "8 credits" option is not available);
The Tech2 can validate 3, 5 or 8 credits (the "1 credit" option is not available);
The Tech3 can validate 1, 3, 5 or 8 credits; they must commit at the beginning of the year in order to validate the "Innovation" Roadblock

BONUS: The validated contribution to an open source project renamed during the year entitles you to 1 additional credit if you validate one of these steps (validated contribution == pull request).

Le développement personnel est un travail de toute une vie. C'est une façon de cerner ses compétences et qualités, ses objectifs dans la vie, et une manière de se fixer des buts, afin de réaliser et maximiser son potentiel.

Module.name: S0 - Security - Binary
Module.description:
Binary Security:

TOPICS COVERED: 

A study of the vulnerabilities associated with application development. A non-exhaustive list of areas covered:

* Reverse Engineering:
  * Anti-debugging techniques (Corrupted ELF format, stripped binaries, Packing, checksum on the binary itself, stack corruption, ptrace etc.)
  * Different Architectures/Formats: Elf, PE, x86, x64, ARM  

* Exploitation
  * Vulnerabilities
    * Buffer Overflow
      * Stack Based
      * Heap Based
    * Integer Overflow
    * Use after free
    * Format string
  * Techniques
    * Debugging (r2 / GDB)
    * Ret-to-X (code, libc etc.), Stack pivot, ROP
    * Loading binaries (auxvv, GOT / PLT)
    * Bypassing protections (NX, ASLR, ASCII-Armor etc.)
    * Malloc Des-Maleficarum Houses


TIMELINE: 

There is only one project for this unit. Over the course of the project's duration, the goal is to take advantage of the weaknesses and obtain the permissions or informations for the infrastructures that were set up for the project. It is a platform in which groups of students compete and try to obtain the highest score, sometimes at the cost of the other teams.  

Before the project, a CFP will be held in order to organize short-talk sessions and student-lead workshops. 


VALIDATION CRITERIA: 

A broad knowledge of reverse and detecting and exploiting applicative vulnerabilities will be among the criteria needed to validate the unit.

Module.name: S0 - Security - Web
Module.description:
Web Security -- SHODAN:

SUBJECTS COVERED: 

Study of vulnerabilities linked to the development of Web applications. 
Non-exhaustive list of domains we will cover:  
Authentification, ACL, configuration, cryptography, encoding, error management, protocols, synchronization, language traps, Web Services, injections.


CLASS OUTLINE: 

There is only one project for this unit: SHODAN.
Throughout the duration of the project, the goal is to succeed in exploiting weaknesses and obtain privileges or information on sites set up for the project.
It's a platform on which groups of students will compete and look to obtain the highest score, sometimes at the cost of other teams.
Before the project, a CFP will take place in order to organize short-talk and workshop sessions that will be lead by students. 


VALIDATION CONDITIONS: 

Skill domains:
- Web pentest environment 
- bruteforce technique, developing simple operations 
- Client security: XSS/CSRF/Phishing
- Various injections: headers HTTP, SQL, URL, code, file, command

General knowledge of the detection and operation of these problems will be a condition to validate this unit.

On top of that, you may be asked to register - or will be registered by the teacher - for Guidance meetings, once in the cycle.

When necessary, you will take part in Cold Case sessions, where the teacher will help you tackle grammar or methodology difficulties.

Module.name: B0 - English
Module.description:
This cycle lasts 5 weeks.

A presentation is organized to introduce you to the new English module.

The names of the projects are greek letters, the topics of the projects are written as subtitles.

Cycle 1 encompasses a limited number of projects.
A kick off is organized on the first day of the cycle, to introduce the topics of the projects.

Each project lasts 5 weeks: 
- 4 weeks of training and preparation (through workshop sessions, once a week);
- 1 week of testing (through a delivery session). Test sessions may be individual or group evaluation, depending on the project. The goal is to check if you have acquired the skills expected from you (5 skills per project).

On top of that, you may be asked to register - or will be registered by the teacher - for Guidance meetings, once in the cycle.

When necessary, you will take part in Cold Case sessions, where the teacher will help you tackle grammar or methodology difficulties.

Module.name: B3 - C++ Seminar
Module.description:
The C++ Seminar (or Pool) is a key moment in Epitech training. 
Like the C-Seminar unit, it is intensive and highly instructive.

We would advise you not to take it lightly and to work as seriously, and as consistently, as possible throughout the entire three weeks.

TOPICS TO BE COVERED 
You will discover object-oriented programming through the fundamental elements of the C++ language. Classes, instances and methods will (almost) no longer be a secret! 

SKILLS TO BE ACQUIRED in order to validate this unit:
- Correct usage of the C++ language and its special features in relation to C.
- The ability  to produce a basic C++ program in Unix.
- The ability to wake up early, be punctual and work regularly
- The ability to be precise in the reading, and comprehension, of one's code.

Module.name: B3 - Internship
Module.description: This unit materializes your second year internship.

Module.name: B4 - Administrative Meetings
Module.description:
The goal of the Administrative Meetings unit is to keep you up-to-date concerning the administrative evolution of your academic career.

Through a various number of conferences, the pedagogical staff will recap the current status of the graduating class, the major events of the year and the best practices you should remember to follow.

Enrollment in this unit is mandatory.

Module.name: B4 - Computer Numerical Analysis - CryptoTrading
Module.description:
Execution of the Trade project

THE PROJECT:
The goal of this project is to play around with stock market prices.
In other words, buying and selling stock according stock market's prices.
Of course, just like in real life, you won't know which price the stock will have; it's an "interactive" system. 

GENERAL MAP :
In order to support you in achieving your own algorithm, this unit is made up of the following elements:
 - a first project to introduce THE most used tools in the stock market field for decision taking (sell/buy/wait).
 - a second project "Trade", that takes you to the elaboration of your own algorithm.
This project will be evaluated during a three-hour event, with a real-time stock market index, on which you'll have to apply your own algorithm and improve it live (dress up!)
You will be ranked according to your profits.

Module.name: B4 - FR - Écrits professionnels
Module.description:
Module obligatoire sur le cycle:

Vous devez valider 2 modules d'écrits professionnels du cursus Bachelor pour votre passage en Tek4.


-------------------
Le module B4 d'écrits professionnels comporte trois projets à réaliser :
mail professionnel de recadrage d'un collègue, diaporama et bilan d'expérience.
Les compétences sont validées sur la base de plusieurs projets réalisés.

Ces projets consistent à produire des documents écrits de qualité professionnelle. Il s'agit d'écrits variés.
Ils vous placent dans des situations différentes et vous préparent à savoir rédiger plus facilement et plus efficacement vos écrits professionnels.

Les situations d'écriture de ce module sont: contrôler le ton dans un écrit professionnel, susciter l'intérêt, tirer le bilan d'une expérience professionnelle ou personnelle.

Chaque projet du module active des compétences rédactionnelles communes à tout écrit professionnel.
De plus, il vous permet de vous familiariser avec des techniques rédactionnelles spécifiques.

Chaque projet est précédé de cours consultables en libre accès sur l'E-Learning (Semestre 4 / B4-Expression écrite) et de TD de techniques rédactionnelles.

En complément, des suivis sont organisés à destination des étudiants qui ont des difficultés à surmonter en orthographe et en grammaire.

De plus, des ressources d’auto-formation sont mises à disposition des étudiants pour les aider à résoudre des difficultés ponctuelles (accord des participes passés, ne pas confondre à, a et as, etc.). 
Ces ressources sont en libre accès sur l'E-learning (Semestre 0 / Auto-formation écrits professionnels).

Tout au long du module, vous aurez ainsi l'occasion d'acquérir des techniques rédactionnelles efficaces et de vous perfectionner pour écrire des documents pertinents.

A la fin du module, vous devez être capable :

1) d'écrire pour être lu et compris (s'adapter à son public et être clair)
2) de contrôler le ton à adopter (en fonction de la situation, du destinataire, du type d'écrit)
3) de susciter l'intérêt (savoir mettre en valeur quelqu'un ou quelque chose)
4) de faire le bilan d'une expérience (prendre du recul, analyser, synthétiser)
5) de livrer des écrits soignés (qualité de l'orthographe et clarté de la mise en page)

Vous serez évalué sur ces compétences lors de sessions d'évaluation planifiées auxquelles la présence est obligatoire.

Module.name: B4 - Hub
Module.description: This unit does not include activities and is only intended to carry the credits obtained thanks to the activities carried by module "B0 - Hub"

Module.name: B4 - Professional Competencies
Module.description:
This unit is mainly composed of review sessions.

The reviews allow you to present what you've done on a project, explain why you've done it this way and how you accomplished this result.

The code reviews allow you to share your programming experience and get feedbacks from peers. 

2 of the credits depends on your participation and quality of your reviews.
To gain 1 more credits, you must participate to at least 3 code reviews.

Module.name: B4 - Unix Prog. - Memory
Module.description:
Next installment of the first year's UNIX system programming unit. All projects are to be exclusively done in C/UNIXX (given that it's the next installment of the 1st year's PSU), except when explicitly stated otherwise in the subject:  

- Memory allocation management (brk(2), sbrk(2), malloc project)

In order to validate this unit, you must show, through your project, that you have acquired the following skills: 

- Understanding of the mechanisms of memory management 
  (in particular the links between physical memory and virtual memory); 
- Understanding of the structure of a binary(ELF) file format

Module.description: We will discuss modularization and problematic' abstraction by using practical examples such as dynamic libraries and threads when using the OOP paradigm.
